sen.j: 川崎 正蔵（かわさき しょうぞう、天保7年7月10日 (旧暦)（1836年8月10日） - 大正元年（1912年）12月2日）は日本の実業家、政治家。
sen.e: Shozo KAWASAKI (10 August, 1836 - 2 December 1912) was a Japanese politician as well as an entrepreneur.
Shozo KAWASAKI (August 10, 1836 – December 2 1912) was a Japanese politician as well as an entrepreneur.
sen.cmt: 日付の変更をしました。
sen.e: Shozo KAWASAKI (August 10, 1836 – December 2 1912) was a Japanese politician as well as an entrepreneur.

sen.j: 神戸川崎財閥の創設者。
sen.e: He was the founder of the Kobe Kawasaki combine.
He was the founder of the Kobe Kawasaki combine.
He was the founder of the Kobe Kawasaki combine.

sen.j: 川崎造船所創業者、貴族院議員。
sen.e: He was the founder of Kawasaki Shipbuilding Corporation as well as a member of the House of Peers.
He was the founder of Kawasaki Shipbuilding Corporation as well as a member of the House of Peers.
He was the founder of Kawasaki Shipbuilding Corporation as well as a member of the House of Peers.

sen.j: 男爵。
sen.e: He was a baron.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れに対応しました。
sen.e: He was a baron.

sen.j: 幼名・磯治。
sen.e: His childhood name was Isoji.
His childhood name was Isoji.
His childhood name was Isoji.

sen.j: 薩摩国鹿児島城下大黒町（鹿児島県鹿児島市）生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Daikoku-cho near Kagoshima Castle in Kagoshima Province (currently Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture).
He was born in Daikoku-cho near Kagoshima Castle in Kagoshima Province (currently Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture).
He was born in Daikoku-cho near Kagoshima Castle in Kagoshima Province (currently Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture).

sen.j: 17歳の時長崎に出て貿易に従事、藩命によって金・米を扱った。
sen.e: He moved to Nagasaki at the age of 17 and engaged in trading which he handled gold and rice due to the domain order.
He moved to Nagasaki at the age of 17 and engaged in trading, in which he handled gold and rice due to the domain order.
sen.cmt: 文法の変更をしました。
sen.e: He moved to Nagasaki at the age of 17 and engaged in trading, in which he handled gold and rice due to the domain order.

sen.j: 鹿児島町吏、さらに大坂の蔵屋敷用達を命ぜられたが、貿易に着目して藩庁を説き、西洋型帆船数隻を購入して薩摩国産物を畿内に輸送、巨利を博した。
sen.e: Although he was assigned as a Kagoshima municipal officer and Kurayashiki-warehouses officer, he convinced the domain to purchase a few Western sailing ships and gained an enormous profit by transporting goods from Satsuma to eastern region.

Although he was assigned as a Kagoshima municipal officer and Kurayashiki-warehouses officer, he convinced the domain to purchase a few Western sailing ships and gained an enormous profit by transporting goods from Satsuma to eastern regions.

Although he was assigned as a Kagoshima municipal officer and Kurayashiki-warehouses officer, he convinced the domain to purchase a few Western sailing ships and gained an enormous profit by transporting goods from Satsuma to eastern regions.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）上京し、明治6年（1873年）帝国郵便汽船会社副社長となり、東京、琉球間の郵便航路開始に尽力した。
sen.e: After moving to Tokyo in 1871, he became the vice-president of Japan Mail Steamship Company in 1873 and worked hard to open up the sea route for mail service between Tokyo and Ryukyu.
After moving to Tokyo in 1871, he became the vice-president of Japan Mail Steamship Company in 1873 and worked hard to open up the sea route for mail service between Tokyo and Ryukyu.
After moving to Tokyo in 1871, he became the vice-president of Japan Mail Steamship Company in 1873 and worked hard to open up the sea route for mail service between Tokyo and Ryukyu.

sen.j: 同社は明治11年（1878年）に三菱汽船会社と合併する。
sen.e: In 1878, the company was merged with Mitsubishi Steamship Company.
In 1878, the company was merged with Mitsubishi Steamship Company.
In 1878, the company was merged with Mitsubishi Steamship Company.

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年）大阪に官糖取扱店を開き、また琉球反物の運送販売により巨利を得て、念願であった造船業を開始。
sen.e: In 1877, he opened up a company handling sugar and also gained an enormous profit by transporting Ryukyu fabrics which enabled him to start his long-cherished business, a shipbuilding company.
In 1877, he opened up a company handling sugar and also gained an enormous profit by transporting Ryukyu fabrics which enabled him to start his long-desired business, a shipbuilding company.
In 1877, he opened up a company handling sugar and also gained an enormous profit by transporting Ryukyu fabrics which enabled him to start his long-desired business, a shipbuilding company.

sen.j: 明治11年（1878年）築地造船所、明治13年（1880年）兵庫川崎造船所を開業、明治19年（1886年）には官営兵庫造船所の払い下げを受けて、明治20年（1887年）川崎造船所（現・川崎重工業）を設立。
sen.e: He established Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878, Hyogo Kawasaki Dockyard in 1880 and Kawasaki Dockyard (now known as Kawasaki Heavy Industries) in 1887 after the disposal of Hyogo Dockyard owned by the government in 1886.

He established Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878, Hyogo Kawasaki Dockyard in 1880, and Kawasaki Dockyard (now known as Kawasaki Heavy Industries) in 1887, after the disposal of the government-operated Hyogo Dockyard 1886.

He established Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878, Hyogo Kawasaki Dockyard in 1880, and Kawasaki Dockyard (now known as Kawasaki Heavy Industries) in 1887, after the disposal of the government-operated Hyogo Dockyard 1886.

sen.j: 明治29年（1896年）川崎造船所を株式に改組し、顧問に退いた。
sen.e: In 1896, Kawasaki Dockyard took the company public, and he became an advisor after retiring from his position.
In 1896, KAWASAKI reorganized Kawasaki Dockyard into a public company, and he retired to the position of an advisor.
In 1896, KAWASAKI reorganized Kawasaki Dockyard into a public company, and he retired to the position of an advisor.

sen.j: 事実上、後継者がいなかった正蔵は、同郷の先輩であり自分の事業の恩人でもあった松方正義の三男・松方幸次郎を後継者に選ぶ。
sen.e: Since Shozo did not have any children to take over his business, he chose Kojiro MATSUKATA, the third son of Masayoshi MATSUKATA, as his successor due to Masayoshi coming from the same village as himself and being the benefactor in the early days of the business.

Since Shozo did not have any children to take over his business, he chose Kojiro MATSUKATA, the third son of Masayoshi MATSUKATA, as his successor due to Masayoshi coming from the same village as himself and being the benefactor in the early days of the business.

Since Shozo did not have any children to take over his business, he chose Kojiro MATSUKATA, the third son of Masayoshi MATSUKATA, as his successor due to Masayoshi coming from the same village as himself and being the benefactor in the early days of the business.

sen.j: 一方、明治23年（1890年）に多額納税貴族院議員、明治31年（1898年）「神戸新聞」を創刊、明治38年（1905年）神戸川崎銀行を開設、監督に就任した。
sen.e: In the meanwhile, he became a high tax paying member of the House of the Peer in 1890, published 'Kobe Newspapers' in 1898 and was appointed as the chairman of Kobe Kawasaki Bank which he established in 1905.

Meanwhile, he became a high tax paying member of the House of the Peer in 1890, published 'Kobe Newspapers' in 1898, and was appointed as the chairman of Kobe Kawasaki Bank which he established in 1905.

Meanwhile, he became a high tax paying member of the House of the Peer in 1890, published 'Kobe Newspapers' in 1898, and was appointed as the chairman of Kobe Kawasaki Bank which he established in 1905.

sen.j: また美術品の収集でも知られ、神戸の自邸内に美術館をつくり、長春閣と名付けた。
sen.e: He was also known as an art collector and had a museum named Choshunkaku in his own house.
He was also known as an art collector and made a museum named Choshunkaku in his own house in Kobe.
He was also known as an art collector and made a museum named Choshunkaku in his own house in Kobe.

tit.j: 美術蒐集家としての正蔵

sen.j: 明治29年に第一線を引退してからの川崎正蔵は、造船事業家としてよりもむしろ美術蒐集家として社会的に有名であった。
sen.e: He was more commonly known as an art collector than as an industrialist in the shipbuilding business after his retirement in 1896.
He was more commonly known as an art collector than as an industrialist in the shipbuilding business after his retirement in 1896.
He was more commonly known as an art collector than as an industrialist in the shipbuilding business after his retirement in 1896.

sen.j: 正蔵は仕事で他家を訪問するごとに、家屋や庭園、さらに床の間の書画、置物、装飾品にいたるまで、深い注意を払うのを常とし、これがおのずから美術鑑賞眼を養った。
sen.e: On each occasion Shozo visited other houses for his work, he paid close attention to not only the houses and gardens but also calligraphic works and paintings displayed in a tokonoma, ornaments and decorations, which helped to develop his eye for arts.

As Shozo visited other houses for his work, he paid close attention not only to the houses and gardens but also to the calligraphic works, paintings, ornaments, and decorations displayed in the tokonoma, which helped to develop his eye for arts.

As Shozo visited other houses for his work, he paid close attention not only to the houses and gardens but also to the calligraphic works, paintings, ornaments, and decorations displayed in the tokonoma, which helped to develop his eye for arts.

sen.j: そして、家屋、庭園、美術品は川崎の唯一ともいうべき趣味であり、自分の大志を励ます何よりの刺激剤であった。
sen.e: Houses, gardens and arts were his only hobbies, and this helped to keep his ambitions encouraged.
Houses, gardens and arts were his only hobbies, and this helped to keep his ambitions encouraged.
Houses, gardens and arts were his only hobbies, and this helped to keep his ambitions encouraged.

sen.j: 川崎の美術蒐集は、彼の造船業への参入の動機と同じように、明治時代に生きた人間らしいナショナリズムに基づくもので、すなわち明治維新後には日本の伝統的な美術品は欧米の美術愛好者のために輸出されることが多くなり、多くの名品が日本で見られなくなる状態が出現しつつあった。
sen.e: Kawasaki's involvement in the art collection was similar to the reasoning behind his involvement in the shipbuilding business, which was based on the nationalism of people who lived in the Meiji Period, and that is to say Japanese traditional arts were exported to art collectors in Europe and the United States which left very few masterpieces to be admired in Japan after the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: 人間らしいナショナリズムをhumanly nationalismと訳すと意味不明になるのでnationalismと訳しました。
sen.e: Kawasaki's involvement in the art collection was similar to the reasoning behind his involvement in the shipbuilding business, which was based on the nationalism of people who lived in the Meiji Period, and that is to say Japanese traditional arts were exported to art collectors in Europe and the United States which left very few masterpieces to be admired in Japan after the Meiji Restoration.

Kawasaki's involvement in the art collection was similar to the reasoning behind his involvement in the shipbuilding business, which was based on the nationalism of people who lived in the Meiji Period, and that is to say Japanese traditional arts were exported to art collectors in Europe and the United States which left very few masterpieces to be admired in Japan after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 川崎はこのような伝統的美術品が国外へ流出することを恐れる心情も手伝って、明治11年に築地造船所をの経営に着手したころからおりにふれて美術品を蒐集し始め、生涯にわたって2000余点の名品を買い集めた。
sen.e: Since Kawasaki was concerned about traditional artworks being exported to foreign countries, he began collecting them at around the time of starting Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878 and purchased more than 2,000 masterpieces in his lifetime.

Since Kawasaki was concerned about traditional artworks being exported to foreign countries, he began collecting them at around the time of starting Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878 and purchased more than 2,000 masterpieces in his lifetime.

Since Kawasaki was concerned about traditional artworks being exported to foreign countries, he began collecting them at around the time of starting Tsukiji Shipyard in 1878 and purchased more than 2,000 masterpieces in his lifetime.

sen.j: そして明治18年から着工した神戸の布引の豪壮な本邸内に美術館を建てて、自分の蒐集した名品を陳列し、一般に公開した。
sen.e: He built a museum at his magnificent house in Nunobiki, Kobe which began construction in 1885, and his collections were open to the public.
He built a museum at his magnificent house in Nunobiki, Kobe which began construction in 1885, and his collections were exhibited and open to the public.
He built a museum at his magnificent house in Nunobiki, Kobe which began construction in 1885, and his collections were exhibited and open to the public.

sen.j: その所蔵品の中でも、とくに中国の元時代の名画家である顔輝の「寒山拾得二幅対」や、春日基光画「千手千眼観音」（いずれも後に国宝に指定された）は世間で有名であった。
sen.e: Among his collections, 'Kanzan Jitttoku Nifukutsui' by a famous Chinese artist from the Gen Period, Ganki and 'Senju Sengen Kannon' by KASUGA no Motomitsu (both were later designated as national treasure) were quite well known.

Among his collections, 'Kanzan Jitttoku Nifukutsui' by a famous Chinese artist from the Gen Period, Ganki and 'Senju Sengen Kannon' by KASUGA no Motomitsu (both were later designated as national treasure) were quite well known.

Among his collections, 'Kanzan Jitttoku Nifukutsui' by a famous Chinese artist from the Gen Period, Ganki and 'Senju Sengen Kannon' by KASUGA no Motomitsu (both were later designated as national treasure) were quite well known.

sen.j: しかし彼の蒐集した美術品の多くは、後に昭和2年の金融恐慌の際に川崎家が危機に陥った時に、売却される運命にあった。
sen.e: However, most of his collections were sold in order to save the Kawashima when financial crisis was generated in 1927.
However, most of his collections were sold in order to save the Kawasaki, when they were caught in a financial crisis in 1927.
However, most of his collections were sold in order to save the Kawasaki, when they were caught in a financial crisis in 1927.

sen.j: 川崎は美術愛好家として高名であっただけでなく、自ら美術品の製作にも乗り出している。
sen.e: Kawashima was not only well known for being an art lover but also for creating artworks of his own.
Kawasaki was not only well known for being an art lover but also for creating artworks of his own.
Kawasaki was not only well known for being an art lover but also for creating artworks of his own.

sen.j: 彼は明治29年ごろから、明代の万暦七宝に匹敵できる七宝焼を完成することを志し、尾張七宝焼の後継者であった梶佐太郎一族を30年に神戸に呼びよせ、布引山に七宝焼の工場を設けて研究させ、3年後には見事な七宝の製作に成功した。
sen.e: When he began aiming to create cloisonné wares in 1896 which were as good as Banreki cloisonné from Ming Dynasty, Owari cloisonné successor Sataro KAJI and his entire family were sent to Kobe in 1897 to research on the cloisonné wares in a studio built on Mt. Nunobiki where they successfully created beautiful cloisonné wares 3 years later.

When he began aiming to create cloisonné wares in 1896 which were as good as Banreki cloisonné from Ming Dynasty, Owari cloisonné successor Sataro KAJI and his entire family were sent to Kobe in 1897 to research on the cloisonné wares in a studio built on Mt. Nunobiki where they successfully created beautiful cloisonné wares 3 years later.

When he began aiming to create cloisonné wares in 1896 which were as good as Banreki cloisonné from Ming Dynasty, Owari cloisonné successor Sataro KAJI and his entire family were sent to Kobe in 1897 to research on the cloisonné wares in a studio built on Mt. Nunobiki where they successfully created beautiful cloisonné wares 3 years later.

sen.j: そして明治33年にパリで開催された万国博覧会に大花瓶と大香炉を出品して名誉大賞を獲得した。
sen.e: He displayed the big incense burner and vase in World Exposition held in Paris in 1990 and won the grand prize of honor.
He displayed the big incense burner and vase in World Exposition held in Paris in 1990 and won the grand prize of honor.
He displayed the big incense burner and vase in World Exposition held in Paris in 1990 and won the grand prize of honor.

sen.j: 彼はその後も七宝の名品を多く製作したが、1品も売却せず、「川崎の宝玉七宝」と名づけて美術愛好家に贈ることを喜びとしていた。
sen.e: Although he carried on producing beautiful cloisonné wares which were named as 'Kawasaki's jewel cloisonné wares,' no items were being sold since he found joy in giving them away to art lovers.
Although he carried on producing beautiful cloisonné wares which were named as 'Kawasaki's jewel cloisonné wares,' no items were being sold since he found joy in giving them away to art lovers.
Although he carried on producing beautiful cloisonné wares which were named as 'Kawasaki's jewel cloisonné wares,' no items were being sold since he found joy in giving them away to art lovers.

sen.j: このパリ万国博覧会 (1900年)に出席するために、川崎は7人の一族を引き連れてヨーロッパを巡遊し、イギリスの造船業と諸国の美術工芸を見てまわった。
sen.e: In order to attend World Exposition Paris, Kawasaki took 7 family members to Europe where they viewed the shipbuilding industry of England and arts from various countries.
In order to attend World Exposition in Paris, Kawasaki took 7 family members to Europe where they viewed the shipbuilding industry of England and arts from various countries.
In order to attend World Exposition in Paris, Kawasaki took 7 family members to Europe where they viewed the shipbuilding industry of England and arts from various countries.

sen.j: そしてこれが最後の華々しい社会的活動であった。
sen.e: This was his last glorious social activity.
This was his last glorious social activity.
This was his last glorious social activity.

sen.j: その後は体調を崩し、健康の回復を第一の目標として、全国各地の別荘をめぐる「富豪の隠居」が川崎正蔵の実像であった。
sen.e: After that, he became ill and visited his villa all across Japan to prioritize his health, and 'a wealthy person's retirement' was the word to describe Shozo KAWASAKI's lifestyle around this time.
After that, he became ill and visited his villa all across Japan to prioritize his health, and 'a wealthy person's retirement' was the word to describe Shozo KAWASAKI's lifestyle around this time.
